title: labour mp lied speeding wont resign jesus
story: Fiona Onasanya MP faces jail after her conviction on Wednesday for perverting the course of justice to dodge a speeding fine.She was slammed for lying “persistently and deliberately”.But in a defiant message to colleagues the church goer hinted she would come back – like Jesus.In a Whatsapp posting leaked to The Times, the  year-old said “this was not her end but rather the beginning of the next chapter” of her “story” – as it was with the son of God.And appearing to protest her innocence, she told colleagues she was in good biblical company along with Joseph, Moses and Daniel.She said: While God did not save them from a guilty verdict he did save them in it and ensured that their greatest days of impact were on the other side of a guilty verdict.Of course this is equally true of Christ who was accused and convicted by the courts of his day and yet this was not his end but rather the beginning of the next chapter in his story.Please pray that my family will find peace and strength in his perilous time through this guilty verdict.She added that her first jury had failed to reach a verdict - and while she “vigorously maintained my innocence” a second found she was guilty.The MP – made a party disciplinarian by Jeremy Corbyn’s team after her  Election success – said: “Regardless of what you believe or suspect, the fact remains that I Fiona, sought to be the choice and voice of change.“But this may now take a dferent path.”The MP for Peterborough was found guilty of conspiring with her brother to avoid the speeding fine. The Old Bailey heard she was texting as well as speeding at mph in a mph zone. She named former lodger Aleks Antipow as the driver but was in Russia at the time.Labour has called on the solicitor to resign – triggering a by-election in Peterborough. The  year-old was only elected in  with a majority of  votes.Her win was one of the biggest upsets of the Election.“I, Fiona,” she says with impossible grandness, “sought to be the voice of change. This may now take a dferent path.” It  may . . . all the way to prison.

title: putin backs theresa may over brexit second referendum
story: The Russian president, who has long been accused of undermining faith in Western democracy, also revealed ambitions to repair the relations between the two countries.Speaking at his annual news conference, Putin warned the British PM she must respect the will of the people.He said: In terms of Brexit,it is carried through to the end, I can understand the prime ministersposition...There was a referendum after all. What can she do She must enact the will of the people, expressed during the referendum.The Russian leader confirmed Moscows relationship with London is still deadlocked but Mr Putin said he wanted to restore UK-Russia ties from their current low.He said: It is in the interests of both countries, both governments to get out of this deadlock.Are we interested in restoring full relations with Britain  Yes, we are interested.The relationship between the UK and Russia collapsed following the poisoning of former spy Sergei Skripal and his daughter Yulia in Salisbury.UK police identied Russian operatives Alexander Mishkin and Anatoliy Chepiga as the instigators behind the attack after they used the nerve agent novichok.But Moscow has continued to deny the claims and Putin dismissed Britains stance as a politicised, Russophobic approach.He said: Its good that he wasnt killed... Thank God, Skripal is alive.Its simply an excuse to organise yet another attack on Russia.If there were no Skripals, they would have come up with something , thats clear to me.Elsewhere in the marathon press conference, Putin issued a chilling threat about the end of all civilisationRussias nuke row with the US escalates.

title: universal credit iain duncan smith support campaign
story: It was complex, impersonal and so punitive that people out of work kept as little as p in every pound they earned when they found a job.It left people stranded on low hours and so was bad for businesses, bad for the taxpayers, and devastating for the inidual.And so a simpler system, that allows you to keep more of your income, was designed and is working. Compared with the old welfare system, people are more likely to find work, stay in work, and earn more money.However, there ARE problems - as The Sun’s powerful Make Universal Credit Work campaign has brilliantly highlighted. Families have shared their stories of waiting weeks for their first payment, of children losing their nursery places because of delays in childcare payments and of the high taper rate meaning it’s not worth their while to work longer hours.The Government must listen to the Suns campaign. I particularly support the call to keep reducing the taper rate – the effective tax on benefits as you go into work. Our original design of the system was for a rate of  percent. The Government has already brought it down from  percent to  percent and it should go further.Likewise, the call for childcare support is welcome and mirrors ideas from the Centre for Social Justice.Childcare can be complex and expensive to navigate – anything that makes it more affordable and simpler is welcome.One million people are already receiving it and by the time the system is fully rolled out in , nearly  million will be on it.But there are big problems with the flagship new system - it takes  weeks to get the first payment and it could leave some families worse off by thousands of pounds a year.And while working families can claim back up to  per cent of their childcare costs, they must find the money to pay for childcare upfront - we’ve heard of families waiting up to  months for the money.Working parents across the country told us they’ve been unable to take on more hours - or have even turned down better paid jobs or more hours because of the amount they get their benefits cut.It’s time to Make Universal Credit work. We want the government to:Together, these changes will help Make Universal Credit Work.Join our Universal Credit Facebook group or email UniversalCredit@the-sun to share your story. For the aim of Universal Credit is to simply six dferent benefits into one single claim. It lets them keep more of the money they earn. And, crucially, it gives claimants a single work coach to guide them through the process.When fully rolled out, best estimates are that Universal Credit will help between , and , more people into work, those already in work to earn more, and those in part-time work will to move to full-time.And with two-thirds of people coming onto Universal Credit bringing signicant debt with them, it shows the deeply ingrained problems of what went before.It’s also worth reminding ourselves that when Tax Credits rolled out, nearly  million people never got their benefits.But there have been some problems with the implementation of Universal Credit.Firstly, cuts to the system in  have made transition onto it harder and drove my own resignation in part. I have, alongside organisations, such as the Centre for Social Justice, have since campaigned to see those cuts reversed.It is to the current Government’s great credit that they have re-invested about £ billion of the £ billion taken out, but it can go further. Investing in Universal Credit should be a priority.A system that supports work is itself a health policy with huge benefits.The educational outcomes for a child in a working household increase - girls who grow up in jobless households spend an average of two years less in school than those whose parents work, and boys spend one year less. If we want to tackle the current mental health problems in the UK, work has a vital role to play.Secondly, the design of the new system is meant to help people get work ready. Fundamentally Universal Credit is not just a tool for financial support but for changing lives.It does this in part by using online applications, helping people take responsibility for their own rent, and receiving their income in monthly arrears like a pay cheque.But for some people, particularly those with dficult and chaotic lives, this change, though important and right, has been hard to navigate.Some payment flexibility has now been added but it’s time to invest in Universal Support [programmes that help people making a claim for Universal Credit and give them online money support - such as budgeting advice].This support package was designed to run alongside Universal Credit and help support those in the greatest need but has been all too thinly rolled out.For the most vulnerable in society, this aspect is crucial, and must become a priority. As should the areas for change that The Sun is highlighting in its campaign.The Sun is right, a full-time job is still the single best way out of poverty, which is why making Universal Credit work should be our priority because as Joseph Rowntree said, properly rolled out, UC has the greatest capacity to tackle poverty.

title: don mccullin photography exhibition tate vietnam
story: The exhibition includes black and white scenes of the Vietnam war, The Troubles and the recent conflict in Syria.As well as capturing the horror of war-torn countries, the iconic photographer focuses on the trials and tribulations of what is happening on our doorsteps.McCullin recorded scenes of poverty and working class live in Londons East End and the industrial north.Two young boys posed in front of brick wall spray-painted with No Nazis in Bradford.The photographer risked his own le to capture the breathtaking images, sheltering from bullets as he took the photographs.In contrast to the bleak scenes of poverty in London he spent time shooting the rolling hills and glorious landscapes of his hometown of Somerset.One of the photos on display features a homeless Irishman in Spitalfields, London in .The whites of his eyes are striking against his dull and dirty skin tone - of which half is hidden behind a wispy white beard.His hair so filthy that it is beginning to clump together and form natural dreadlocks.In one shot, a lone protestor sat down with his sign in front of a dozen police officers in Trafalgar Square in .Sir Don McCullin was born in  and grew up in a deprived area in North London as it was bombed by Hitlers Nazis during World War II.He was the first photojournalist to be awarded a CBE and worked for  years in some of the worlds notorious war zones.McCullin has worked in Africa, Asia and the Middle East but his career began after he photographed a London gang named The Guvnors.He presented the gang shots to the picture editor at The Observer in , aged , earning his first commission.In  he won the British Press Award for his essay on the construction of the Berlin Wall.His first taste of war came in Cyprus, , where he covered the armed eruption of ethnic and nationalistic tension, winning a World Press Photo Award for his efforts.Over  photographs, all printed by McCullin himself in his own darkroom will go on display at the Tate from Feburary next year.

title: nikon photo competition 2018 amazing images
story: The camera firm has hosted the challenge since  and it has resulted in all sorts of weird and wonderful snaps.Entries have gotten even more spectacular since more and more amateur snappers invested in digital cameras over the last ten years.Wildle, sports, architecture and the majesty of nature are all covered in this wondrous collection of pictures from around the world and down the ages.Swooping bats, stunning Buddhist temples and jumping monoskiers are all captured as contestants vie for the crown and £, prize.Nikon describes its contest as an aspirational community that supports photographers and filmmakers who wish to share important stories and influence the way people think through images.

title: defence budget world power plea
story: Tobias Ellwood said France was on course to replace Britain as the European nation with the biggest military budget next year.And he revealed China’s navy is growing by the size of our navy each year.He wants the PM to up the military budget from  per cent of the UK’s economic output to between . per cent to  per cent.The current budget is £billion - compared with America’s £billion.Writing in today’s Sun, the Minister says: “We retain the most professional Armed Forces in the world, brilliantly trained and well equipped.We know that countries such as Russia and China are asserting themselves both regionally but their actions will soon global consequences challenging our security, stability and prosperity.And of course extremismis far from defeated.Our adversaries now challenge us below the traditional threshold of tradition conflict, in the ‘grey zone’, that sits between war and peace- where the rules are vague.Assassinations, information warfare, interference with supply chains, cyber attacks, fake news - all go gain advantage and sow confusion.The first responsibility of any Government is to defend country.But Britain does more than that.We have a long established reputation of not only looking after our own interest but of our allies too.Thanks to our history, our valued relationships and leadership, we have a unique perspective of the world.Our respected soft power allows us to play an influential role on the international stage as a force for good.This justies our permeant seat at the UN Security Council Yet as the world becomes more dangerous and complex– ever fewer countries retain the ability to step forward and challenge this new instability.If this trend in instability continues to go unchecked it will become the norm.So our Defence Modernisation Programme, announced by Gavin Williamson this week, is a timely and ambitious plan to upgrade our defence posture.But this will require investment - confirmed at the next Spending Review.If we are to secure further defence spending the nation must demand it.So let’s first have an honest conversation with the nation about our current capabilities, the threats that loom ahead and the consequences to our way of lewe do not upgrade.Russia and China know our strengths and weaknesses better than the public does.So we must use the Modernisation Programme to bury the myths that the nation’s relative security is not a given and the international rule book that’s helped keep the relative peace for a generation is now out of date.Russia’s level of aggression remains on the accent.The capture of three Ukrainian ships last month illustrate how they are ever exploiting new ways to assert their influence.Kremlin sponsored bots pollute conversation in democratic nations across the world, and military intelligence service GRU has been caught out operating a series of indiscriminate cyber attacks.Their digital technology is developing at a breath-taking pace.China’s military influence in the East Asia seas and now across Africa continues go advance.Their navy is growing by the size of our Navy every year.And they continue to rush to dominate G, the next generation of cellular technology which will revolutionise our lives.Dominance of data ownership is China’s mission - effectively controlling the internet and the world’s connectivity.We retain the most professional Armed Forces in the world, brilliantly trained and well equipped.But whilst the Royal Navy and RAF have enjoyed some impressive equipment advancements the Army is still using a Main Battle Tank and Armoured Personnel Carrier that’s not been upgraded in two decades.Russia’s on its third iteration in the same timeframe.But its not just in the conventional space where the Defence Secretary wants to invest, but in the domains of cyberspace and space - where the absence of established rules provide the most scope for hostile action.Areas such as AI, autonomy, directed energy weaponscan manoeuvre a hypersonic speeds.They are evolving at an incredible speed and must act to retain our competitive edge.Simply put, without investment in our hard power, we will not keep up an we will unable to respond to this fast changing world.Effectively removing ourselves from that international leadership role which we have prided ourselves for decades.And it is leadership that’s needed to recognise the tried and tested diplomatic instruments and conventions that we relied on to keep the peace are no longer fit for purpose.Exploitation of new technologies is un-regulated.So which nation is willing to step forward a call and help write a new International rule book This is not just a clever call for increased defence spending but a recognition that access to Britain’s physical and digital international markets will need protectingour post Brexit economy is to continue to prosper.The proposal modernise and transform defence will ensure we remain, nog just engaged and committed - but physically able to defend our values and our way of le.It’s now for the British people to make the choice.“But whilst the Royal Navy and RAF have enjoyed some impressive equipment advancements, our Army is still using a Main Battle tank and Armoured Personnel Carrier that’s not been upgraded in two decades.”He added: “The danger is without investment in hard power we will be unable to respond evenwe want to. It’s not just about money for defence but by investing now we invest in our prosperity.”The blast comes after Mr Ellwood – who served as a captain in the Royal Green Jackets – risked the ire of No. by criticising Donald Trump for pulling out of the Syrian conflict.On Twitter he said the President was wrong to assume the war against Da’esh was “won”.The Minister – who memorably tried to save PC Keith Palmer in the Westminster terror attack – said Britain had to adjust its military capability to reflect the changing threat from the “grey zone”.He said the Ministry of Defence was already looking to invest in Articial Intelligence and areas such as energy weapons – lasers.He added: “We must be honest - our soft power will diminishwe don’t invest in our hard power.”Defence Secretary Gavin Williamson earlier this week said the UK had to be prepared to fight wars with AI and in space.And, unveiling a Modernising Defence Programmehe insisted Britain had to try and “keep pace” with its nation-state competitors.Mr Ellwood said the MDP programme was “a timely and ambitious plan to upgrade our defence posture”.But he said: “It will require investment – confirmed at the next Spending Review.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: next year hottest record 2018 heatwave met office
story: After this years sweltering temperatures, we could be in for another dose of tropical weather in .Forecasters have predicted that the average global temperature next year will be around .C above pre-industrial levels.Warming from El Nino and rising levels of greenhouse gases are the contributing factors to next years sizzling summer.Since ,  is the warmest year weve had on record with a central estimate of .C above the same baseline. Professor Adam Scae, head of long-range prediction at the Met Office said: Our forecasts suggest that by the end of ,  of the  warmest years on record will have occurred since the year .Forecasts issued by the Met Office at the end of  for global temperatures this year were closely in line with what has been seen in .Dr Doug Smith, Met Office research fellow, said: The forecast for  would place next year amongst the five warmest years on record, which would all have occurred since .All of these years have been around C warmer than the pre-industrial period.Whilst warm summers are always a welcomed delight for Brits, its also a sign that the planet is in trouble.Experts have warned that we need to take urgent and dramatic action to bring down emissions rapidly in a bid to fight global warming.

title: britains prosperity brexit small businesses
story: But it is Britain’s businesses that will get us out of it.Whatever happens in our negotiations with the EU, this country will depend for its prosperity after Brexit — as it always has — on millions of businesses, up and down the land selling, exporting and innovating.It is these firms that have made us a great trading nation, and the fth largest economy in the world.But there is a problem.The “voice of business” heard in Whitehall is not the voice of business.It tends to be the voice of the Confederation of British Industry , which is dominated by the comfortable incumbents and large multi-nationals.Family firms — those owned and run by one person, or by members of the same family — make up the overwhelming majority of Britain’s businesses.These .million firms employ .million people, or almost  per cent of workers — and pay enough tax to fund the entire NHS.They are at the heart of our communities, rooted in their lives. Yet all too often, their needs are ignored.My own family started as blacksmiths in Uttoxeter, Staffs.In , my father, Joseph Cyril Bamford, rented a lock-up garage for  shillings a week.He developed Europe’s first hydraulic tipping trailer for use by local farmers — and then, in , the backhoe loader, the classic JCB digger.JCB — JC Bamford Excavators Ltd — has produced more than a million machines.We have a turnover of more than £billion and factories around the world.Yet we remain a proud ­family business, headquartered in the Midlands and employing thousands of people there.Ours is not a unique success story. Yet it is rarer than it should be.Our main factory in Staffs used to be surrounded by thriving family manufacturers, mostly in the Black Country, Birmingham and Manchester.Over the decades, they have disappeared — because of tax regimes that made it impossible to pass firms on, or takeovers that stripped away what was special about the company, or government mandarins who thought they knew better what industry needed.In Germany, their world-class manufacturing sector thrives because they champion family firms, not least via tax breaks that make it normal for ownership to move across generations.In Britain, the tax system pushes entrepreneurs to sell up, and family businesses find it harder to get finance.No wonder that fewer than  per cent expect to keep their firm in the family.Yet we at JCB still have many excellent family firms among our suppliers — and our customers.In manufacturing, there are more than a quarter of a million family companies, employing more than a million people in jobs that add real value to the community.And such firms are found in every sector of the economy, not just ours.A company such as JCB is big enough to stand up for, and speak for, itself.But too many small firms do not get a hearing in government.Despite the fact that small and medium-sized enterprises — SMEs — are creating almost three times as many jobs as larger firms, it is the voice of the giants that dominates.Yes, these large firms contribute enormously to the economy, but they tend to be the most comfortable with the status quo.They might moan about regulation but they can afford to deal with it, knowing that it deters their smaller competitors.They see Brexit, for example, in terms of costs, rather than opportunities. This is reflected in government.Theresa May’s approach to Brexit was safety-first, focusing on protecting the cross-border supply chains of the multi-nationals.Yet  per cent of British firms do not export. Their main worries are to do with competition and regulation.But regulation, in particular, is harder to addresswe are still following European rules — as is striking new trade deals.Protecting the big companies means reducing opportunities for little ones.I voted, proudly and publicly, for Leave.I believe there is nothing to fear in trading on World Trade Organisation terms, as we at JCB already do — exporting to, and importing from, dozens of countries around the world.But this is not about Brexit. Millions of business owners throughout the country feel they are not represented or spoken for.Polling by Deltapoll recently found that even Tory voters do not think their party is on the side of small business.For the politicians who listen to these firms, the rewards will be political as well as economic.I have spent my le working in a family business.I believe family businesses, of all sizes, are tied to and invested in their communities in a way other firms can never be.And I worry that Britain has a model of tax, regulation and politics in which everything is arranged to suit the big firms on the FTSE, not those that might one day hope to replace them.Whatever the outcome of the Brexit wrangling, we can only succeed long termwe make Britain the best place in the world to start, run and keep a business of your own.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: The retired Marine Corps general – a hugely respected figure among soldiers and military chiefs – is to leave his job in February.Trump made the announcement in a tweet, saying that Mattis was “retiring with distinction” and had made “tremendous progress” in the role.Shortly after, Mattis’ resignation letter made it clear that he and Trump – who do not share the same views on keeping US troops in Syria – had parted ways because of policy dferences.The US President is pulling , troops from the war-torn country – after declaring the war against IS won – and is reportedly looking at doing the same in Afghanistan.Mattis’ resignation letter, released by the Pentagon, said: “Because you have a right to a Secretary of Defense whose views are better aligned with yours…I believe it is right for me to step down from my position.”Trump said he would nominate a successor to Mattis shortly.Mattis joins a long list of former Trump administration senior figures who have either quit or been removed, including Secretary of State Rex Tillerson who Trump fired via Twitter in March.Trump’s White House has had the highest turnover of senior-level staff of the past five presidents, according to the Brookings Institution think tank.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: Crimbo crowds in Cardf refused to let torrential rain dampen their moods while sozzled Santas were seen getting merry in Leeds on whats been dubbed Thirsty Thursday.The bars were packed as Brits marked the end of the working year ahead of Mad Friday, also known as Black Eye Friday, which is the last Friday before Christmas.Christmas time is always a busy night for the emergency services and last night looked like no exception.Police could be seen leading one man away in handcuffs in Birmingham while paramedics had to stretcher someone into an ambulance in Blackpool.This holiday season Brits were predicted to neck up to  units of alcohol during their work Christmas party – the maximum amount a person should consume in a WEEK according to the NHS.

title: animals hide plain sight photos
story: These amazing animals are true masters of disguise blending effortlessly into their environment as a means of survival in the natural world.From frogs to fish and bugs to birds this collection of images, from a whole host of photographers all over the world, shows the animal kingdoms outstanding ability to blend into the background.For humans the power to be invisible is something many of us can only dream of, but for a whole host of animals, camouflage is the best tool they have in the constant struggle to survive.Animals use two basic methods of concealment in a bid to hide from predators and catch prey.These are general resemblance and special resemblance. With general resemblance animals use colour to blend in with their background until they are almost invisible.This method is most commonly associated with chameleons but other creatures including spiders and the Hymenopus Coronatus - also known as the Orchid Mantis - adopt this tactic when hiding and hunting.Special resemblance sees creatures use a mixture of shape, colour, texture and behaviour to make them appear like something  in their habitat such as a leaf or a twig.Take a look at these photographs and seeyou can spot the hidden creatures in each one.Some are harder than you might think.

title: schoolgirl eats advent calendar cats catnip
story: Alissa Evans, , had complained that her £. advent calendar chocolates looked funny but full-time mum Jess Evans thought shed bought the purr-fect gt.After clawing her way through four days’ of the green-tinged treats from a Garfield calendar, disgusted Alissa told -year-old Jess she didn’t like them and refused to eat any more.The mum-of-three was horried when she turned the box over to find the apple flavoured chocolates were yoghurt and catnip delicacies — for cats.Jess, from Oswestry, Shropshire, said: I was in shock and felt like the worst mother ever when I realised I’d bought her a calendar for cats.She said they tasted a bit strange, but hadn’t said they were horrible, so I just forgot about it.Alissa hadn’t been eating them for a few days and when I asked why she brought the box over to me.I remember thinking they did look a funny shade of green and didn’t have a chocolatey smell.When I turned the calendar over and read that it was yoghurt and catnip flavour I couldn’t believe it - and that it had taken  days for us to notice.Jess had picked the advent calender up while out shopping with Alissa and her younger sisters Alexis Davies-Evans, three, and -month-old Aurora Davies-Evans in BM.Jess said: I was rushing around at the last minute with all three of them Christmas shopping and went into BM where all the advent calendars were and picked it up without reading it.On the th of December I was opening the younger girls’ calendars but Alissa said she didn’t want hers and had stopped eating them.“When I looked at the box I couldn’t believe it. I have a degree in English literature and creative writing but still couldn’t read a calendar and it had taken me  days to realise.“Once she got over the shock she found the funny side of it. Thankfully she’s absolutely fine and I’ve checked online that she will be ok.“I’m going to give the calendar to my friend for her cat.”

title: universal credit brit abroad not eligible
story: Former train manager Matthew Stockall, , ed from Benidorm to the UK last month after the breakdown of his relationship and struggled to find work, so applied for help on the new welfare system.He was shocked to find out from the DWP that because hed not been living in the country, then he wasnt able to access help.Matthew was born and bred in Manchester but moved to Benidorm two years ago to be with his former partner.But after ing back to the country and having to move in with his mum hes been unable to find work and has had to rely on friends and family for food.He said he was living off just £ a week after leaving his bar job in Spain: The DWP told me they didn’t recognise me a resident of the country as I had no permanent residence or offer of employment.I received an email saying I had failed the Habitual Residency Test.I explained to Universal Credit that I had paid tax for the entirety of my le before moving, to which they replied by saying that a lot of other people in the same position had paid more than me in their letime.The news comes after The Sun launched our Make Universal Credit Work campaign to help thousands who are struggling with the system.Today ex-DWP boss Iain Duncan Smith urged ministers to listen to our campaign and acknowlege the problems with the current system.Writing for The Sun, he said: For some people, particularly those with dficult and chaotic lives, this change, though important and right, has been hard to navigate.And while working families can claim back up to  per cent of their childcare costs, they must find the money to pay for childcare upfront - we’ve heard of families waiting up to  months for the money.Working parents across the country told us they’ve been unable to take on more hours - or have even turned down better paid jobs or more hours because of the amount they get their benefits cut.It’s time to Make Universal Credit work. We want the government to:Together, these changes will help Make Universal Credit Work.Join our Universal Credit Facebook group or email UniversalCredit@the-sun to share your story. Matthew went on: I have paid National Insurance and tax for almost  years before moving, and when I needed help my country didn’t listen.Since ing, I’ve had no help and relied on what my auntie and sister could offer me.I’ve had to sofa hop between their homes, as well as relying on them to feed me.Hes now living in Northwich, Cheshire, which he says has limited job opportunities as he cant drive.If I didn’t have the support of my family, I would have been on the streets and deemed unfit to contribute to the country, or to any company when looking for work.He says he thought the reason he was rejected was because they thought he wouldto Spain.After an intervention from Mikes MP, Mike Amesbury, hes now getting help from Universal Credit.A spokesman from DWP said: We have an obligation to ensure we support people who are fully resident in the UK to avoid abuse of the welfare system.The Habitual Residence Test ensures that only people intending to remain within the UK for the foreseeable future can claim welfare support.This includes ing UK nationals, and we will always speak to claimants and examine evidence for this.

title: stowaways cargo ship thames estuary
story: An Italian vessel called the Grande Tema is currently just off the coast of Margate, Kent after setting off from Lagos, Nigeria last Monday.The ship, built in , is due to dock in Tilbury, Essex today.The Dover Shipping Strait Facebook page posted earlier: BREAKING: Piracy in the Thames Estuary....Reports coming in of stowaways aboard Grande Tema threatening the crew. Incident is ongoing.Nige Scutt, an experienced marine photographer who runs the page explained: I had calls from two separate sources.One said it was stowaways on board.But the other said that stowaways had come out and made their presence known and have taken over areas of the ship or the vessel itself and threatened the crew in the process.If that is the case then that is piracy.You normally hear of this off the Horn of Africa - not the Thames Estuary.The , tonne ship was due to dock at Tilbury but has been moving slowly up and down in the area known as Margate Roads anchorage area.Essex Police were today keeping tight-lipped about the incident but stressed no one had been injured.They denied the incident involved piracy and said there were no armed police involved.They also ruled out a hostage or terror-related incident but refused to give any more details.An Essex Police spokesperson said: We continue to deal with a complex incident on board a vessel that is in the Thames Estuary close to the Essex and Kent borders.This follows a call relating to the safety of crew on board at around . am today, Friday, December .We have received no reports that anyone has been harmed and dont believe they are at risk.We are not currently treating this as either a hostage, piracy or terror related incident.We are working closely with our partners to resolve this incident as quickly as possible.A statement from the Maritime  Coastguard Agency read: HM Coastguard is currently assisting Essex Police with an ongoing incident on a vessel in the Thames estuary.

title: meghan markle prince harry grenfell community kitchen adele
story: The Duke and Duchess of Sussex went to the Hubb Community Kitchen which provides support for the families of the Grenfell Tower fire.Meghan, who is currently expecting her first child with Harry, previously helped to raise £, for the kitchen and wrote the foreword of a charity cookbook of recipes inspired by the group.The visit was made all the more special by the fact that it was Prince Harrys first appearance at the centre.But the royal couple werent the only famous faces at the kitchen last night as pop star Adele also dropped by to see the work the women there have been doing.Pictures of the singer with women at the kitchen were widely shared on social media.Munria Mahmoud, of the founders of the kitchen, wrote online: Had the pleasure of cooking for Adele  days in a row. title: polish prime minister come home brexit
story: Mateusz Morawiecki said today after a joint press conference with Theresa May that he wanted Poles to come back to their home country to help their blooming economy.His comments came just after Mrs May had urged Poles to stay in the country after we leave, insisting they are more than welcome here.Mr Morawiecki said: We are happy that they have found a new home.However as our economy is blooming we’d like our citizens to consider ing to Poland, although we respect everyone’s personal choices.Around one million Polish citizens live and work in the EU at the moment, but not everyone will be able to come here after we leave and new immigration rules kick in.After talks with Mrs May this afternoon he said the Brexit deal on the table was the best deal possible and would be beneficial for both sides.It comes just hours after he blasted harsh Jean Claude Juncker for ridiculing Theresa May and derailing Brexit.Mr Morawiecki lashed out at his colleagues in the EU such as Mr Juncker, who sparked a huge row last week for calling the PM nebulous.He gave Mrs May support for getting her deal passed, but will warn the EU has to buck its ideas up.And he said in an interview with the Daily : Sadly, the Brexit case has brought to light rather unfortunate behaviour.Strong statements and harsh words of some politicians in Brussels do not help, but hinder our common goal in achieving the most desirable outcome for all.The Polish PM added in support for Mrs May: Stakes are high, opinions y, and so emotions run strong. But there is no doubt that Mrs May represents the British nation and that must be recognised by all.The PM thanked her Polish counterpart for the support after the Salisbury spy attack in March this year.Russia was found to behind the attack on Sergei Skripal and his daughter Yulia, when their door handle was sprayed with Novichok.Dawn Sturgess tragically died after coming into contact with the container days later on.Today Mrs May revealed the UK would share intelligence and expertise to set up a new unit in Poland that directly counters Russian disinformation, and ensures quick attribution of hostile activity against state or commercial targets.The Polish PM reiterated the threat from our eastern neighbours still exists, and called on the Nato alliance to remain strong in the face of them.He said it was not the darkest hour but believes that Theresa May can navigate through the storm.And he praised her for fighting hard to get the best deal for the UK.The Polish PM has long been an ally of Mrs May in her EU talks.But Mr Morawiecki said that getting the deal through the Commons depended on EU leaders attitude towards the UK.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: michael mcintyre big show gino
story: He comes to Britain to work as a chef but ends up in prison, for two years, after robbing singer Paul Young’s house.Somehow or other, though, his cookery skills land Gino a television gig and the public is so enchanted by his Mind Your Language personality they chant “GI-NOOOH, GI-NOOOH” whenever he enters a studio, and force him to change his name to “Sheffield”, by actual deed poll, because they don’t quite believe he’s really Italian.It was deranged enough then, even before Saturday night, when BBC viewers saw footage of comedian Michael McIntyre sneaking into Gino’s house, at one in the morning, waking him up abruptly and demanding he identy the dancing cartoon character he’d brought with him.“He’s a sponge man,” a half-asleep Gino began blustering, to audience guffaws.“Bob the sponge. Bob, for sure. The sponge with the Bob and the shorts ”At which point, things started getting even weirder for Gino on Michael McIntyre’s Big Show.A programme which, I realise, wasn’t the main television event of the weekend. That was the Strictly Come Dancing final.But so what  It’s Christmas, and after  months largely spent telling you what television shows I don’t like, it seems only fair to celebrate one that I do. Why Simple. Michael McIntyre is one of the very few comedians left on television who realises it’s his duty to make viewers laugh rather than bend and bully them into their left-wing point of view.A noble calling, obviously, but there’d be no point taking this mainstream approachthe resulting show was also cheesy, unprofessional and talked down to its audience.Michael McIntyre’s Big Show falls into none of those traps. Apart from being riotously funny, it’s also clever, charmingly savage at times and ided into three equally slick segments that can all carry an embarrassing musical interlude from Cheryl Tweedy, who stamped around, in elephant leggings, like a mad woman on Saturday’s show.They take it in turns to be the highlight of the show as well. A fortnight ago Bradley Walsh’s send-to-all stunt was the best bit.Last week it was the unexpected-star-of-the-show slot and, at the weekend, it was undoubtedly the Midnight Gameshow with Gino, who had eight stabs before sort of nailing: “SpongeBob with the square pants.”His torment was only just beginning, however, as he was then asked to ID the mystery celebrity singing in his shower.Easy in normal circumstances, but, right on cue, Gino had developed a: “First thing in the morning moment”, and had to shuffle next door with a pillow hiding his embarrassment.If he had the problem, though, Michael McIntyre definitely had the solution.“It’s Sinitta!” he yelled, killing the “first thing in the morning” problem stone dead, which was probably just as well, because he was hugging Boycie from Only Fools And Horses a second or two later.It wasn’t just Gino’s physical responses that were the making of this stunt, though, it was the fact that, having been presented with all this random madness, as well as a goat called Olivia, he asked the single best television question I’ve heard all year.“Are we live ”“LIVE ” responded McIntyre, barely able to contain himself. “It’s one in the morning, Gino.”It’s tempting, then, to describe the whole thing as television perfection.Perfection, though, would’ve involved Gino asking, as he did: “Who comes to houses at this time of the evening ” and McIntyre opening his bedroom cupboard door with a “TA-DA! Paul Young does, Gino.”A Dominatrix on C’s The Sex Business: Pain For Pleasure B Head of Drama at the BBC THE BBC really has created a Sports Personality Of The Year show in the image of its co-host Clare Balding and her all-consuming inferiority complex, hasn’t it A vast and murky event that clearly thinks it’s an adorable, all-inclusive, finger-on-the-pulse, rock ’n’ roll jamboree but is actually a nerdy, uptight, controlling, gender-obsessed, PC quota-thon of the most self-deceiving kind.So Tyson Fury, who has a genuine personality, was excluded from the final six, but Billie Jean King was all over proceedings and England’s Common-wealth Games netball women were apparently the “team of the year”.SPOTY was at its absolute worst, though, trying to do populist, celebrating the all-conquering England World Cup football team , with some BBC-approved patriotism.That is to say, a multi-cultural version of Three Lions, featuring Bhangra dancers, a steel band and a gospel choir, without whom, the BBC presumably imagined, England fans would be goose-stepping round the NEC burning crosses.No one can say for surethis ill-judged segment influenced the final vote, won by Welsh cyclist Geraint Thomas, of course, but Harry Kane started the night as favourite and ended it third, after something  happened during the song that was so horrendous and disturbing no one who heard the incident can ever mention it or the offender ever again.I hope you’re bloody proud of yourself, David Baddiel.The Time It Takes, Joe Lycett: “Who wrote the Keats poem Ode To A Nightingale ”Joe Lycett: “Which American state is home to the Dallas Cowboys ”And  to , Sandi Toksvig: “What five-letter word for a native of one of the Scandinavian countries is also a British name for a root vegetable similar to a turnip ”GOOD Morning Britain, Tuesday Piers Morgan: “The lady who brings our food in has announced she’s quitting. Why ” : Repetitive strain injury. : Lost her HGV licence. : Slipped a disc with a crate of doughnuts. : All other Piers-is-a-fat-bandit suggestions.ROYAL Variety Performance update.Rhod Gilbert: “It’s six years since I did any stand-up comedy.”Six years, five minutes and  seconds.Danny Dyer making a foul-mouthed idiot of himself on The Jonathan Ross Show.Tight-fisted BBC cliche Steph McGovern ordering a £ bottle of Dom Perignon champagne because someone  was picking up the bill on I’ll Get This.Channel ’s Sex Business: Pain For Pleasure episode being interrupted by a too-much-information advert for Morrison’s “vacuum-packed pork.”And The Royal Variety Performance imagining “Edinburgh Festival comedy winner” was any reason to book “comedian” Rose Matafeo, whose routine was so self-indulgent and dreadful proceedings were genuinely lted by the obituaries.Sent in by Ireenie, via email. Picture research Alfie Snelling.Danny Murphy: “The free-kick was on the half-way line, deep in United’s half.”Les Ferdinand: “You can see that there’s no way you can see that.”Graeme Souness: “If you’re standing still, you’re going backwards.”THE four Strictly Come Dancing finalists “smashed it,” “nailed it,” went on several “roller-coaster rides,” and at least  journeys on Saturday night.To be honest with you, though, I noticed almost none of them, as I was too absorbed by the reappearance, in Claudia Winkleman’s balcony, of Seann Walsh who was the main reason many of us non-dance fans kept watching the series.The weird thing about Strictly, of course, is that it cannot mention its love triangle or the tantalising rumours about Danny John-Jules’ bullying behaviour, let alone the fact that, technically speaking, the fourth best dancer won because the public is clearly fed-up with professionally trained celebrities.It’s a situation that’s unlikely to change next series, though, because I get the impression Strictly is too full of itself and so set in its ways it hasn’t even noticed the last judging  score should be given to Craig Revel Horwood, who would provide a welcome punchline to the gener-osity of the other three.There’s no real incentive for it to change either. The ratings were triumphant, the BBC’s very own Eliza Doolittle lted the glitterball and, for the briefest of moments, during her wild dress-swishing paso doble, viewers all thought they glimpsed the true signicance of her gong.She is Stacey Dooley MBE, My Brazilian’s Exposed. And don’t you forget it.Claude Littner leaving Daniel’s handshake hanging at the ever-brilliant Apprentice interviews.Kurran mentioning himself in the same breath as “Tarantino and Scorsese”, directing Sian’s bikini advert in the final.Debra Stephenson, Rod Woodward and Adrienne Warren, as Tina Turner, all doing their best to save the Royal Variety Performance. Eamonn Holmes pitching up at The Heart Attack Grill, on his C Vegas jaunt .And Goggleboxer Pete, in Blackpool, explaining the response to Theresa May’s Brexit deal better than any political pundit: “It’s like when you shout ‘OGI OGI OGI” and no one goes “Oi Oi Oi.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: NewsMinisters wont rule out a foreign government being behind Gatwick drone chaosTransport Secretary Chris Grayling steered the BBC towards an eco-group being responsible - but also didnt rule out a foreign power and said he "genuinely" doesnt knowShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video chris-grayling-refuses-rule-out-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTory ministers have refused to rule out the possibility a hostile foreign government is behind the Gatwick drone chaos. The Transport Secretary admitted the assembled government, military and police genuinely dont know who ruined more than , peoples Christmas plans in the last  hours. Asked by BBC Radio a foreign power could be responsible, Chris Grayling replied: I don’t want to speculate on that. We genuinely don’t know who it is or what the motivation was. I think it’s unlikely to be but at the moment I’m not ruling out anything.” Mr Grayling said there had been a number of drones at Britains second-biggest airport and the culprit could be a rogue lone wolf or a group actor. He added: It could be an environmental protest but we genuinely don’t know.”  But he added: “Its certainly not linked to terrorism in the conventional sense.” Mr Grayling said those responsible should go to jail for a long time”. He added: “They can face a jail sentence and should face an extended jail sentence.” It comes weeks after Gatwick revealed plans to open a second runway by bringing into operation its emergency landing strip for routine take-offs and landings.Mr Grayling said “military capability” is being used to stop the drones at Gatwick together with commercially-available methods.  “Its a new kind of attack that we are going to have to make sure we are prepared for,” Mr Grayling told the BBC.“This is an entirely new kind of threat and we are going to have to move quickly.” Defending his handling of the chaos, he insisted: “There is no single, simple solution off the shelf deliverable very quickly.” He also condemned those who suggested the drones be shot out of the sky. He said literally thousands of machine gun bullets” had been shot at drones before without removing them from the air. “You can’t just fire weapons haphazardly in what is a built up area around an airport,” he added.

title: boy 2 left infertile after
story: NewsBoy, , is castrated after surgeons operate on wrong testicleThe toddlers parents say they knew something wasnt right when the operation they were told would last  minutes went on for more than two hoursShareCommentsByAmber HicksRod Minchin:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsThe Bristol Royal Hospital for Children where the operation was carried out "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA distraught mother says her two-year-old sons future has been destroyed after surgeons operated on the wrong testicle and left him infertile. The youngster was admitted to Bristol Royal Hospital for Children earlier in the week to treat an undescended testicle. And his family were told it was just a minimal operation with minimal risk and it would be over in around  minutes. But after two and a half hours his parents say they were left waiting and waiting before being told that the operation wasnt a success and surgeons operated on the wrong one by mistake, castrating him. The boys devastated father told the BBC: They destroyed everything and they ruined my son. The hospital trust has since apologised and launched an investigation.  The youngsters dad, whose name has not been revealed to protect his sons identity, said his sons undescended testicle was discovered during a routine check-up. The toddler was referred to a specialist and on Monday he was booked in for an operation at the Bristol Royal Hospital for Children, which would last around  minutes. We were waiting and waiting, his father said. After two and a half hours the manager, surgeons and consultants they came and I knew something was not right. Me and my we started panicking, they called us into the office and told us things didnt go right and the operation wasnt a success. The couple said they were told a surgeon had mistakenly inserted a camera into the wrong side and now their sons healthy testicle would never work. I was very distressed, it was an awful disaster for a simple operation, his father added. They castrated him and now my sons future le has dramatically changed.  The boys mother said it was absolutely horrible what the surgeons had done. They broke my heart and they basically destroyed his future, she said. I cant find the words to explain how Im feeling - there are no words. Even tears, I have no more tears. We just hope for a miracle, this is what we hope. In a statement, Trust medical director Dr William Oldfield said: On behalf of the Trust, I am deeply sorry that a serious incident has occurred in the treatment of a young child in our care and would like to offer our sincerest apologies. As soon as our staff realised what had happened they met with the family to offer their apologies and explain what had happened. We take patient safety and standards of clinical care very seriously and have begun a thorough investigation into this matter and will work with the family throughout this process. I would again like to offer my apologies to the family for this incident.

title: brave woman who survived breast
story: NewsBrave woman who survived breast cancer shares topless picture after cruel jibesLaura Owens, from Merseyside, was just  when she had her right breast removed after a cancer diagnosisShareCommentsByChantelle HeedsNeil Murphy:,  DEC NewsLaura Owens hit back with the perfect response "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA breast cancer survivor has hit back at men who made cruel comments about her appearance - by sharing a picture of her mastectomy scars. Laura Owens, from Merseyside, took to Facebook and defied their insensitive remarks by saying: I’m a strong f****** woman, not a sex object. She was just  when she had her right breast removed and reconstructed after being diagnosed with breast cancer in .Laura decided to have the other breast removed and reconstructed in , the Liverpool Echo reported.But she started to have a severe reaction to her implant after her second reconstruction, and claims her skin turned yellow, she had pain down her left arm and that she was getting really tired.  Because of this Laura made the brave decision to remove both of her implants in April of this year. Yesterday, the yoga teacher took to Facebook to post her response after two men she used to know made ignorant comments about the way she looks. Laura said: In the last week, I’ve had two male friends, who I haven’t seen in a long time, say to people in front of me: You should have seen Laura in her heyday,  years ago. Rude. Or am I supposed to be grateful that guys used to think I was hot ! If I hadn’t been through everything I have, and was still the girl I was  years ago, it might crush me to hear that. But it doesn’t.  She hit back at comments that her heyday was  years ago, when in reality she has never felt more comfortable in her own skin, also saying she chose to publicly share her experience for the women. Laura added: It makes me laugh that some people think my heyday was when I wore a face full of make up, perfect hair, sexy outfits, padded bras. I.e. dressing for someone ’s approval. F*** that. I’m strong and capable, I stand up for what I believe in. I walk away from people or situations that make me uncomfortable. And I wear what makes me feel happy, not sexy. A lot of my ’s were spent working in the world of high-end nightclubs where image, money and status were everything, and I’m proud that I‘m no longer part of that.  I’m proud that I care more about what I think than what anyone  thinks. Laura takes pride in the fact that she hasnt succumbed to the pressures of botox and fillers, despite that the complications of her implants rapidly aged her skin. She added: This is not me having a digyou’ve had botox, I understand what it’s like to be so self-critical you won’t even leave the house, it’s just that after having my breasts amputated twice through illness, I’ve learned to appreciate my body exactly the way it is.

title: children stranded new zealand christmas
story: NewsChildren stranded in New Zealand for Christmas after horror crash kills mumA GoFundMe page has now been set up to help Ben and Olivia Sargent, six and nine, who were on a dream family holiday with their mums Kerry and Jules SargentShareCommentsByEd Stilliard:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsKerry Sargent, left, from Gloucester, died in a crash in New Zealand in October and her we, Jules, right, is recovering from the crash but is too ill to travel "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTwo children have been left stranded in New Zealand for Christmas after a horror crash killed their mum and left the other in hospital. Ben and Olivia Sargent, six and nine, were on a dream family holiday with their mums Kerry and Jules Sargent. But the trip turned into a nightmare on a night out for dinner with friends when Kerry, from Gloucester, was killed in a head-on collision near Whangarei. The children’s other mum, Jules Sargent, was rushed to hospital with serious, le-threatening injuries, some of which it is expected will take her years to recover from, reports Gloucestershire Live. Currently the -year-old is too unwell to travel, leaving her and theirtwo children spending their Christmas in the city of Whangarei in North Island of New Zealand, north of the capital. Although they were not seriously injured, they have been traumatised and deeply scarred by the incident.   Ben has told his mum he can’t remember the good times before the crash. Both he and his sister are being cared for by friends but a GoFundMe page has been set up in a bid to raise pound, and help them create some magical moments that they can all look forward to. It is hoped these will provide light during the darker times. Family friend Alan York said: “Currently, Jules is recuperating in New Zealand with the friends she went out to visit and will need a substantial period of recovery before the family canto England. “Until then, Ben and Olivia have been schooled in New Zealand while Jules undergoes physiotherapy before the doctors can assess whether she is fit enough to take the children on their long journey home.” In the crash, Jules broke her ribs, right leg and two vertebra, and her toes were dislocated. Her left arm was also injured and she has an open wound to her left hip area which also fractured part of the hip bone. She has been told the injury to her left arm could take up to two years to recover from.   Speaking from hospital in New Zealand Jules said: I was so shocked when Alan first told me about the Magical Memories campaign. I didnt think people would respond in this way to our situation, but it is really comforting to know how much people care and want to help my children. They have been through such a traumatic experience as they were initially stuck in the car whilst it was on its roof and had to be rescued by friends smashing the windows to get them out.It was a terrying experience for everyone but Ben and Olivia have shown so much courage throughout this whole situation. I am so proud of them of both. Ben has said ‘he cant think about the good times before the accident all he can remember is the accident.’ This amazing campaign will be used to help them overcome the trauma and create some more happy memories. Mr York added: Jules’ recovery period is expected to be very y and we, as friends of the family, want to help Ben and Olivia get through what will inevitably be some very tough times over the next few years, given how involved their mums were in all aspects of their lives. With your support, we want to help get the whole family safely home back to the UK and give Olivia and Ben experiences that will enrich their childhood and transform their lives for the better after this terrible experience. To support the campaign, visithttps:www.gofundme magical-moments-for-ben-and-olivia

story: NewsDog owners boycott groomers who stripped traumatised pedigree pooch of all its furLesley and Steve Wilks, from Hull, claim they arranged for Maltese terrier Effy to have only parts of its fur shaved at The Groom Room at Pets at HomeShareCommentsByAlex Grove:,  DEC Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news real-le-stories video dog-mum-outraged-after-pooch-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailDog owners who are angry their pedigree pooch was stripped of all its fur are boycotting the groomers after their pet was left traumatised.Lesley and Steve Wilks claim they had arranged for Maltese terrier Effy to have only parts of its fur shaved after it had become matted, HullLive reports.Mr Wilks left their one-year-old dog to The Groom Room at Pets at Home in Hull on Wednesday morning - after showing staff the matted hair on her two front legs and behind her shoulder. He insists that he told staff he did not want to the dog to be fully shaved - but he was horried toover an hour later and find Effy virtually “pink” after having had her body sheared. Pets At Home have said Effy was shaved for her own welfare due to the extent of the matted fur.   Mr Wilks, , from Kingswood in Hull, said: “I told them I did not want her shaving all over. They said she was matted everywhere but she wasn’t as she’d only been bathed and brushed on Monday. “When I saw the state of her I wanted to shout and start swearing but I didn’t – I kept my cool and I said nothing because I just wanted to get out of the store.” After ing home, Mrs Wilks “burst into tears” when she saw her beloved pet before angrily taking to Facebook to rant about the procedure which she likened to “torture” for Effy.   The -year-old beautician said: “We are absolutely distraught, disgusted and gutted [by] what The Groom Room Pets At Home Hull has done to my baby girl! “Her poor bottom has been completely stripped as has all her fur! Please be aware this place is nothing but a Shave Room! “I hope [you’re] happy and would love to get responses and advice from anyone, as I would love to sue them for what they have done! She has been shaking with anxiety since she ed this afternoon! Their attitude in response has been disgusting!” Mr Wilks said he was even more aggrieved after Pets at Home charged him an extra pound to have Effy’s body shaved.  “Originally it was pound but they put an extra pound on for the satisfaction of shaving her all over which I didn’t want done,” the dad-of-two said. “They offered me the deposit back but they said it in such a nonchalant way I thought they were being clever.” Mr Wilks said he and his we, who have used The Groom Room twice before, went to the pet store because their normal dog groomer was on holiday. However, he said the pair will now boycott the shop after Effy’s shaving which has had serious repercussions on the young pup, according to Mr Wilks. He said: “We wanted to get her done for Christmas like anyone would but now we are going to have to take her to the vet because she is constantly shaking and is even defecating inside.  “They have traumatised her and it’s freezing now so she is constantly shivering. She is pink and it looks like she has just come out of an operation. “They said they would have to shave under her legs which was not a problem. I understood that but the last thing I said to them was ‘don’t shave all over.’”What Pets at Home saysA spokesman for the pet supplies retailer, which has more than  stores and , employees, said: “Ourgroomers are highly trained and will always put the welfare of pets first. “When Effy was brought in to our Hull store to be groomed it was explained that, because her coat was heavily matted, particularly around her legs and shoulders, it would have to be clipped close to the skin, purely for the welfare of the dog. “We believe that clipping a matted coat is kinder, faster and gentler for the pet. Effy’s owner, Mr Wilks, was advised of this, including the additional pound matting charge. “Our groomers offered to refund the deposit and not groom Effy, but the customer agreed to go ahead and signed both our clipping policy, and pet grooming salon contract. “We hope that Effy will be happier and healthier with her matted coat now removed and our expert groomers would be happy to helpMr Wilks has any further concerns.”

title: gatwick passenger stunned easyjet boarding
story: NewsGatwick passenger stunned at easyJet boarding pass showing advert for DRONECustomer Benoît Guilbaud saw the funny side but remarked at the irony of the advert seeing as more than , people have had travel plans ruinedShareCommentsByAmber Hicks:,  DEC NewsBenoît Guilbaud saw the funny side "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn easyJet passenger was stunned when he printed out his boarding pass only to see an advert for a drone at the bottom - amid days of chaos at Gatwick Airport. Luckily Benoicirct Guilbaud, a teaching fellow at the University of Sussex, saw the funny side of it but said: You couldnt make this up. It comes after  hours of chaos for more than , passengers who saw their flights delayed or cancelled after drone sightings at London Gatwick - Britains second busiest airport.Mr Guilbaud added of the ironic advert: The boarding pass for my maybe-cancelled Easyjet flight from Gatwick tomorrow advertises… drones!   The drone drama saw the military and snipers called in to help, while police from the Met and Surrey have joined forces to patrol the area while the operator - or operators - remain at large. Flights were finally able to depart after am this morning - with the first a rather festive one as it was heading to to Rovaniemi, the capital of Lapland in northern Finland. Meanwhile, a bemused Mr Guilbaud who shared the picture of his boarding pass on Twitter has since received an apology from easyJet. They replied: The advert was placed before the issues at Gatwick and has now been removed. We are sorry for any offence.   One person said in response: Dear easyJet - don’t worry, anyone offended should get a sense of humour. Normal people just enjoy the irony. The huge ad was of a DJI Mavic Drone for rent - with a  per cent discount offer for customers. The flying device can be rented from equipment site Tryatec to shoot aerial film for pound per week online - but it is on offer at pound per week for easyJet travellers. This morning, Sussex Police assistant chief constable Steve Barry said the last confirmed sighting of a drone was at pm last night.   He told BBC Breakfast: “The last few days has been unprecedented nationally I would say, I mean we have had minor incursions previously at Gatwick and we have responded to those really effectively. “But like I say, this scenario that we’re dealing with has been unprecedented so in terms of getting the level of options available to respond to it, to mitigate it, to detect it and respond to it, that has taken us some time, but I’m really confident now that we’ve got everything we possibly could have here at Gatwick.” Askedthe disruption was part of an environmental protest, he said: “Well it’s certainly something that we would consider. Yes, I would agree that’s a possibility.   “At this stage we’re certainly not linking it to terrorism, but obviously we keep an open mind and I can understand the perception. “It is, as I say, an unprecedented level of disruption to national infrastructure to the passengers themselves. It’s really really signicant. But in terms of the motivation as I say you know we’re exploring lines of enquiry around that but at this stage we’re not saying that it is terrorist related.” Around  departures are expected to go ahead today, the chief operating officer announced. Chris Woodroofe told Radio ’s Today programme that the airport has currently cancelled  flights - % of the original plan.   He apologised to those affected over the past  hours. When asked why has it taken so long to reopen the airport, Mr Woodroofe said “this incident has demonstrated that there needs to be an awful lot more done to prevent this risk of drones.”Meanwhile, Gatwick is continuing to advise passengers to check the status of their flight with their airline before travelling to the airport.

title: how watch queens speech christmas
story: NewsHow to watch the Queens Speech on Christmas Day: What time is it and which channel The Queens Christmas Speech is an annual tradition that goes back to the sShareCommentsByDaisy Naylor:,  DEC News" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s queen-elizabeth-ii-s-christmas-speech--pic-getty-.jpg"Queen Elizabeth II makes a Christmas Speech every year"Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailFor many families, gathering around the TV to watch the Queens speech is an annual tradition, and a Christmas Day highlight.The Queens first Christmas message was broadcast on the radio in , with her first televised speech broadcast live on Christmas Day in . These days the Queen pre-records her speech in the week before Christmas, and it is broadcast to all  countries of the commonwealth on  December. Heres everything you need to know. When is the Queens Speech  The Queens Speech is at pm on Christmas Day. It typically lasts for ten minutes.  How to watch the Queens Speech You can watch the Queens Speech on BBC One, ITV, Sky One or Sky News, and it will be broadcast on BBC Radio  as well. It will be streamed live on the Royals Facebook and YouTube accounts, as well as BBC iPlayer. Youll also be able to download the Christmas message as a podcast. What does the Queen say in her speech  The Queen chooses the theme and writes her speech herself, and usually looks back at events from the previous year. Last year she decided to speak about the meaning of home, as she reflected on the Manchester terror attack and the Grenfell Tower fire. This year its expected that she will discuss Brexit, as well as mention the marriage of her grandson Prince Harry to Meghan Markle.  Its also likely that shell talk about other milestones in her family, such as the birth of great-grandson Prince Louis, and the wedding of her granddaughter Princess Eugenie. How many people watch the Queens speech  . million people tuned in to watch the Queens speech last year. Since King George Vdelivered the first Christmas message in , there have only been three years where the reigning monarch did not make a Christmas speech. There was no Kings speech in , as Edward VIII had abdicated just a few weeks beforehand, or in . The Queen did not make a Christmas Speech in , as she felt that she had enough TV coverage what with the release of documentary Royal Family, and her son Charles being made Prince of Wales.

story: AdvertorialHow woman was reunited with ambulance crew who saved her le - plus share YOUR thank you messages for paramedicsHeres your chance to say a huge thank you to the brave men and women who come to the nations aidShareByLaura HammondDave Masters:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC Advertorialthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video heartwarming-moment-girl-reunited-paramedics-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAmbulance crews up and down the country are on call  ,  days a year - and they do an amazing job. TV series Inside The Ambulance at Christmas gives the public a glimpse into the incredible work they do and this Christmas its back for a brand new series on W channel. It’s the first time that cameras have been with crews from West Midlands Ambulance Service as they work around the clock during one of their busiest and most challenging times - tackling , emergency calls each day. To celebrate the start of the new series, were looking at some of the incredible stories of patients who have gone on to meet the very paramedics who saved their lives to say a huge thank you. And were inviting you to send your messages of thanks to any ambulance crews up and down the country who might have come to your aid. Simply fill in the form below and well post as many as we can on the Mirror website. To kick off our series of heartwarming reunion stories, heres Cathys tale... It it wasnt for the two ladies who came to rescue me, I wouldnt be here today  A woman who was rushed to hospital by ambulance after developing severe pneumonia was reunited with the crew she credits for helping to save her le. The Nottingham Post told how Cathy Cook was battling a chest infection when she began struggling to breathe at her home in Mansfield. She became so ill that her husband Wayne decided to call  for an ambulance, unaware that the the -year-olds chest infection had developed into pneumonia and had become le-threatening. East Midlands Ambulance Servicecall handler Kyle Thacker was able to keep the couple calm until paramedic Rebecca Ireland and emergency care assistant Gillian Caldwell arrived seven minutes later. The pair decided to rush Cathy to Kings Mill Hospital, giving her oxygen and a nebuliser, which opened her airways and helped her to breathe, on the way there. At the hospital Cathy, who volunteers for mental health charity Mind, was placed into an induced coma for  days to help her recover from her illness. Recounting her brush with death in January , she said: The last thing I remember is being taken into the operating theatre to have pipes put into my throat to help me breathe, and then I woke up  days later in the intensive care unit. When she woke up, Cathys first concern was that she might have missed a Shakin Stevens gig - which wasnt due to take place for another eight weeks. She continues to recover from her illness, but Cathy was well enough to be reunited with the EMAS staff who helped save her le on Monday . She said: It it wasnt for the two ladies who came to rescue me, then I wouldnt be here today. It was so lovely to meet them again and say a proper thank you in person. Husband Wayne, , was particularly pleased to meet Kyle and thank him for keeping him calm during the  call. He said: It was quite scary. Cathy was shivering and sweating but she kept saying she didnt want to call  because she didnt want to bother anyone. But I said I wasnt hanging around so I called . Kyle was so reassuring and it was so good to know that there was someone there at the end of the phone.Theyre back Inside The Ambulance at Christmas on W channel tonight at pm where Simon and Fiona are called to a pregnant woman whos bleeding, while Joe and Hannah blue light to a young lady whos been self-harming.

story: NewsMeghan Markle takes Harry on secret visit to Grenfell kitchen - with another very famous faceMeghan Markle and Prince Harry popped in to see the women at the Grenfell Tower Hubb Community KitchenShareCommentsByRussell MyersZoe ForseyActing Audience Editor:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC News "Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMeghan Markle showed Prince Harry around the community kitchen she worked in to launch her charity cookbook for Grenfell during a secret visit.The expectant parents popped in to the Grenfell Tower Hubb Community Kitchen, which supports people who had their lives ripped apart by the tragic blaze, on Thursday night.
